title:
S-D Mixing and Searching for the psi(1P1) State at the Beijing
  Electron-Positron Coolider

title_detail.value:
S-D Mixing and Searching for the psi(1P1) State at the Beijing
  Electron-Positron Coolider

summary:
The psi(1P1) state can be produced at the Beijing Electron-Positron Collider
(BEPC) in the process psi'-->psi(1P1)+pi(0). We calculate the rate of this
process taking account of the S-D mixing effect in psi'. It is shown that the
rate is about a factor of 3 smaller than the simple result without considering
the S-D mixing effect. Possible detecting channels are suggested and it is
shown that psi(1P1) is able to be found with the accumulation of 30 million
events of psi' at BEPC.

summary_detail.value:
The psi(1P1) state can be produced at the Beijing Electron-Positron Collider
(BEPC) in the process psi'-->psi(1P1)+pi(0). We calculate the rate of this
process taking account of the S-D mixing effect in psi'. It is shown that the
rate is about a factor of 3 smaller than the simple result without considering
the S-D mixing effect. Possible detecting channels are suggested and it is
shown that psi(1P1) is able to be found with the accumulation of 30 million
events of psi' at BEPC.

author: Yu-Ping Kuang
arxiv_comment: 9-page RevTex file. Version for publication in Phys. Rev. D
fulltext:
S − D mixing and searching for the ψ(11 P1 ) state at the Beijing Electron-Positron
Collider
Yu-Ping Kuang

arXiv:hep-ph/0201210v4 12 Apr 2002

China Center of Advanced Science and Technology (World Laboratory), P.O.Box 8730, Beijing 100080, China
and Department of Physics, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China.∗
(TUHEP-TH-01129)
The ψ(11 P1 ) state can be produced at the Beijing Electron-Positron Collider (BEPC) in the
process ψ ′ → ψ(11 P1 ) + π 0 . We calculate the rate of this process taking account of the S − D
mixing effect in ψ ′ . It is shown that the rate is about a factor of 3 smaller than the simple result
without considering the S − D mixing effect. Possible detecting channels are suggested and it is
shown that ψ(11 P1 ) is able to be found with the accumulation of 3 × 107 events of ψ ′ at BEPC.

PACS number(s): 13.20.Gd, 13.30.Eg, 14.40.Cs
Searching for the 1 P1 states of heavy quarkonia is of interest since the difference between the 1 P1 mass M1 P1
and the center-of-gravity (c.o.g) of the 3 PJ mass Mc.o.g = (5M3 P2 + 3M3 P1 + M3 P0 )/9 gives useful information
about the spin-dependent interactions between the heavy quark and antiquark. Theoretical investigations of
the general structure of the spin-dependent interactions and the formula for the spin-dependent potential up to
O(1/m2 ) in the 1/m expansion have been carried out in various approaches [1,2]. Experimentally, neither the
ψ(11 P1 ) state nor the Υ(11 P1 ) state has been found yet1 . The best way of searching for the ψ(11 P1 ) state is to
look for the process
ψ ′ → ψ(11 P1 ) + π 0

(1)

at an e+ e− collider in the τ -charm energy range. Many years ago, the Crystal Ball Group searched for this
process with a negative result, and the obtained upper limit for the branching ratio is [5]
B(ψ ′ → ψ(11 P1 )π 0 ) < 0.46%,

95% C.L.

(2)

for Mψ(11 P1 ) = 3520 MeV. Now the most promising collider for this kind of experiment is Beijing ElectronPositron Collider (BEPC).
Theoretically, a simple single-channel calculation of the transition rate (1) based on the QCD multipole expansion [6,7] using the Cornell potential model [8] was given in our previous paper [9]. The obtained results
are


the branching ratio comes from the experimental error in Γtot (ψ ′ ). Phenomenological determination of the ratio
αM /αE is not so certain [9]. From the theoretical point of view, the two coupling constants should not be so
different, so we roughly take a possible range

In 1992, the E760 collaboration claimed that they saw a significant enhancement in p̄ + p → J/ψ + π 0 at s = 3526.2
1
MeV which was supposed to be a candidate of ψ(1 P1 ) [3]. However, such an enhancement has not been confirmed by the
successive E835 experiment with significantly higher statistics [4].

(4)

in the calculation. We see that the theoretically predicted B(ψ ′ → ψ(11 P1 )π 0 ) is consistent with the Crystal
Ball limit (2), and is not much smaller than the limit, thus it is hopeful that we will find the ψ(11 P1 ) state in
the near future at BEPC.
Since the ψ ′ mass Mψ′ = 3685.96 ± 0.09 MeV is quite close to the DD̄ threshold Eth = 3729.0 ± 1.0 MeV
[10], it is expected that the coupled-channel effect may affect the transition rate. Complete coupled-channel
calculation of the transition rate is tedious. A coupled-channel formulation of the hadronic transitions between
heavy quarkonium states and the transition rates for Υ′ → Υππ, Υ′′ → Υππ, and Υ′′ → Υ′ ππ have been given in
Ref. [11]. Further improved study of the coupled-channel theory of hadronic transitions in the heavy quarkonium
systems will be presented in a future paper. We notice that an important aspect of the coupled-channel effect
affecting the transition rate is the state mixing. From a reasonable coupled-channel model, the unitarized quark
model (UQM) [12], we see that ψ ′ is not a pure 2S state. Apart from negligibly small ingredients (an order of
magnitude smaller), ψ ′ mainly contains ψ2S and ψ1D states. We denote this mixing as
ψ ′ = ψ2S cos θ + ψ1D sin θ,
ψ ′′ = −ψ2S sin θ + ψ1D cos θ.

(5)

The UQM gives θ ≈ −8.5◦ [12]. It is the purpose of this paper to calculate the influence of such an S − D mixing
on the transition rate (1)2 .
Instead of taking a specific model of the coupled-channel effect, we take a simple and phenomenological approach
such as was done in studying hadronic transitions of ψ(3770) in Ref. [13] and in studying radiative transitions of
heavy quarkonia in Ref. [14], i.e., we determine the mixing angle θ by fitting the experimental value of the ratio of
the leptonic decay rates Γ(ψ ′ → e+ e− )/Γ(ψ ′′ → e+ e− ). In the simple Cornell potential model, the so-determined
θ is [13]
θ = −10◦ .

(6)

This is consistent with the mixing angle θ ≈ −8.5◦ in the UQM mentioned above. In this paper, we take an
improved potential model by Chen and Kuang, which reflects more about QCD and leads to more successful
phenomenological results [15]. The potential reads

each other. From Eqs.(17) and (18), we see that the state-mixing effect significantly reduces the rate due to the

The detection of the process (1) depends on the capability of the photon detector. In the two-body decay (1),
2

the energies of ψ(11 P1 ) and π 0 are fixed, i.e., Eψ(11 P1 ) = (Mψ2 ′ +Mψ(1
1 P ) −mπ 0 )/(2Mψ ′ ), Eπ 0 = (Mψ ′ −Mψ(11 P ) +
1

m2π0 )/(2Mψ′ ). π 0 decays 99% into two photons. The two photons in ψ ′ → ψ(11 P1 ) + γ + γ with invariant mass
2
Mγγ
= m2π0 comes mainly from the π 0 decay in (1) 4 since the branching ratios of the cascade electromagnetic
transitions ψ ′ → ηc′ (3590)+ γ → ψ(11 P1 )+ γ + γ and ψ ′ → ψ(13 P2 )+ γ → ψ(11 P1 )+ γ + γ are of the order of 10−5
and 10−6 − 10−5 , respectively [18]. If the momenta of the two photons can be measured with sufficient accuracy,
one can look for the monotonic invariant mass Mγγ as the signal. Once the energies ω1 and ω2 of the two photons
2
2
are measured, the mass Mψ(11 P1 ) can be determined from ω1 + ω2 = Eπ0 = (Mψ2 ′ − Mψ(1
1 P ) + mπ 0 )/(2Mψ ′ ).
1
Now BES has already accumulated 3 × 106 ψ ′ events. According to the branching ratio in (18) and taking into
account a 10% detection efficiency, there can be 102 − 103 events of ψ ′ → ψ(11 P1 ) + γ + γ. Unfortunately, the
present BES photon detector is not efficient enough to do this kind of measurement. So one should take certain
decay products of ψ(11 P1 ) as the signal.
To calculate the branching ratios of various ψ(11 P1 ) decay channels, the crucial thing is to estimate the radiative
decay rate Γ(ψ(11 P1 ) → ηc γ) and the hadronic decay rate Γ(ψ(11 P1 ) → light hadrons). Since state-mixing effect
is supposed to be not important for ψ(11 P1 ), we can simply do the single-channel calculation. In a recent paper
[19], the rate Γ(ψ(11 P1 ) → ηc γ) was estimated by using the spin symmetry

The branching ratio of the process ψ ′ → J/ψ + π 0 is (9.7 ± 2.1) × 10−4 [10], so that this process can also be detected.
However, it can be clearly distinguished from the signal process (1) by the measured value of ω1 + ω2 = Eπ0 since MJ/ψ
and Mψ(11 P1 ) are quite different.

(5.93 ± 0.10)% [10], we obtain
Γ(J/ψ → 3g) = (66 ± 4) keV.

(23)

We first take the conventional perturbative QCD (PQCD) approach to calculate the ratio in Eq.(21), in
which it is assumed that the long-distance effect is factorized into the wave function of the quarkonium (naive
factorization). The leading order PQCD formula for the right-hand side of Eq.(21) has been given in Refs. [20,21].
In the Chen-Kuang potential model, the ratio on the right-hand side of Eq.(21) has been calculated in Ref. [22],
which is 0.515. Thus we obtain
Γ(ψ(11 P1 ) → 3g) = (45 ± 3) keV.

(24)

Then from Eqs.(20), (24) and some ψ(11 P1 ) decay modes with small decay rates given in Ref. [22], we obtain, in
PQCD,
PQCD :

Γtot (ψ(11 P1 )) = (0.51 ± 0.01) MeV,
B(ψ(11 P1 ) → ηc γ) ≈ (88 ± 2)%,

B(ψ(11 P1 ) → light hadrons) ≈ (8.8 ± 0.8)%.

(25)

We see that both ψ(11 P1 ) → ηc γ and ψ(11 P1 ) → light hadrons are detectable, and the most promising mode
is the radiative transition ψ(11 P1 ) → ηc γ.
Next we take the nonrelativistic QCD (NRQCD) approach developed in recent years [23]. NRQCD is a more
sophisticated approach in which the naive factorization assumption is avoided. It has been intensively studied in
recent years and has been applied to studying the hadronic decays of heavy quarkonia [23,24,19,25]. The study
is up to next-to-leading order (NLO) which contains unknown matrix elements of some operators5 . Considering
the large theoretical uncertainty and the large experimental errors in the input data in this study, taking the
leading order (LO) NRQCD result concerning only one matrix element related to the wave function at the origin
is already sufficient for the present purpose. The LO NRQCD result of Γ(ψ(11 P1 ) → light hadrons is [23]
NRQCD :

Γ[ψ(11 P1 ) → light hadrons] = (0.53 ± 0.08) MeV.

(26)

This is very different from the corresponding values in Eq.(24) in the conventional PQCD approach. With the
updated value of ψ(11 P1 ) → ηc γ [cf. Eq.(20)], the NRQCD predicted total width of ψ(11 P1 ) will be slightly
larger than that given in Ref. [23], which is
NRQCD :

Γtot (ψ(11 P1 ) = (1.1 ± 0.09) MeV.

(27)

Then we have
NRQCD :

B(ψ(11 P1 ) → ηc γ) = (41 ± 3)%,
B(ψ(11 P1 ) → light hadrons) = (48 ± 7)%.

(28)

We see that the predictions in [cf. Eqs.(28)] are quite different from those of PQCD [cf. Eqs.(25)]. Again, both
ψ(11 P1 ) → ηc γ and ψ(11 P1 ) → light hadrons modes are detectable, but here ψ(11 P1 ) → light hadrons is
slightly more promising.
Let us first consider the mode ψ(11 P1 ) → ηc γ. We then need to take certain detectable decay channels of ηc
as the signal. Possible modes are ηc → K K̄π, ηc → ρρ, and ηc → π + π − K + K − . The branching ratios are [10]

5

In a recent paper [19], the NLO value Γ(ψ(11 P1 )) → light hadrons = (0.72±0.32) MeV is obtained. It is larger than the
leading order value [cf. Eq.(26)] by 26% which is within the uncertainty (44%) of the NLO result, and may be neglected
relative to the large theoretical uncertainty and the large experimental errors in the input data in this study. Furthermore,
the uncertainty in this NLO result is so large that, together with the experimental errors in the input data, it can hardly
make clear predictions for the final results.

5

B(ηc → ρρ) = (2.6 ± 0.9)%,

B(ηc → π + π − K + K − ) = (2.0+0.7
−0.6 )%.

(29)

Thus we can look for the decay chains
ψ ′ → ψ(11 P1 )π 0 → ψ(11 P1 )γγ → ηc γγγ → K K̄πγγγ,
ψ ′ → ψ(11 P1 )π 0 → ψ(11 P1 )γγ → ηc γγγ → ρργγγ,

ψ ′ → ψ(11 P1 )π 0 → ψ(11 P1 )γγ → ηc γγγ → K + K − π + π − γγγ.

(30)

If BES can accumulate 3 × 107 ψ ′ events in the near future, then from Eqs.(18), (25) and (29), and taking
into account a 10% detection efficiency, we obtain the event numbers of the signals in (30) in the Chen-Kuang
potential model for θ = −12◦ . The results are listed in Table I. The corresponding event numbers in the NRQCD
approach from Eqs.(18), (28), and (29) are listed in Table II. We see that the signals are detectable.
Next we consider the mode ψ(11 P1 ) → light hadrons. We need to look at ψ(11 P1 ) decaying into a certain
exclusive hadronic channel h. As in Ref. [9,22], we assume that

6

 Now, instead of looking for the chains in (30), one can look for
ψ ′ → ψ(11 P1 )π 0 → ψ(11 P1 )γγ → K K̄πγγ,

ψ ′ → ψ(11 P1 )π 0 → ψ(11 P1 )γγ → ρργγ,
ψ ′ → ψ(11 P1 )π 0 → ψ(11 P1 )γγ → K + K − π + π − γγ.

(40)

Taking into account a 10% detection efficiency, the numbers of events for the chains in Eqs.(40) with 3 × 107 ψ ′
events in the Chen-Kuang potential model for θ = −12◦ are listed in Table III (PQCD) and Table IV (NRQCD).
We see that the two decay chains are all detectable, and the chains (30) are more promising in the PQCD
approach, while the chains (40) are more promising in the NRQCD approach.
Comparing the numbers in Table I− Table IV, we see that the NRQCD approach reduces the numbers of
events for the chains (30) by roughly a factor of 2, and increases the numbers of events for the chains (40) by
roughly a factor of 4 relative to the conventional PQCD approach.
The above situation shows that the detection of the chains (30) and (40) is interesting not only for the ψ(11 P1 )
searches at BEPC, but also for providing a test of the difference between the NRQCD predictions and the
conventional PQCD predictions.
In conclusion, our calculation shows that the S −D mixing effect does affect the transition rate (1) significantly.
It reduces the rate (branching ration) by about a factor of 3 relative to the single-channel result [cf. Eqs.(17)
and (18)]. If the photon detector in the future BES III can be efficient enough to measure the momenta of the
two photons from π 0 → γγ, the search for the ψ(11 P1 ) state via the process (1) will not be difficult at BEPC
II. At the present BES, one should tag ψ(11 P1 ) directly via its decay products. Our results in Table I−Table IV
show that the search for ψ(11 P1 ) is possible with the present BES if an accumulation of 3 × 107 ψ ′ events can be
achieved in the near future.
Finally, we would like to mention that we have also calculated the rate of ψ(3770) → J/ψ ππ in the Chen-Kuang
potential model for θ = −12◦ and ΛMS = 200 MeV. The result is Γ(ψ(3770) → J/ψ ππ) = 170 keV (for c2 =
3c1 ), or 37 keV (for c2 = c1 ). This is close to the corresponding values Γ(ψ(3770) → J/ψ ππ) = 160 keV (for c2 =
3c1 ), or 30 keV (for c2 = c1 ) in the Cornell potential model [13]. Together with the results in Eqs.(17) and (3),
we see that the results are insensitive to the potential models used in the calculation as compared with the
uncertainties in the approach.

University, and a grant from BEPC National Laboratory.
